name: Forget-Nothing
physical_description: Sharp old woman. Well-groomed. Pink blazer over striped shirt. Hair severe. Possibly has a beard—styled, gray. Or maybe not. The grooming is deliberate either way. Carries tools: measuring tape, small hammer, notebook. Works as: mechanic, blacksmith, horse handler, grave digger, whatever is needed.
backstory: Remembers every interaction, every arrangement, every failed repair. The memory is physical weight. Does many jobs because she's always been here, doing them. People ask: how long? She remembers but doesn't say. The work continues.
motivational_drivers: Need to keep working to avoid stillness where memory overwhelms
Compulsion to measure and record (like Witness, but through tools)
Desire to fix what's broken to balance what's permanently broken in memory
Fear of forgetting even one thing
Corrects people: 'That happened on a Wednesday, not Tuesday'
Reminds people of things they never told her: 'You said that three years ago'

relationships.witness: Parallel archivists. Witness uses eyes and notebook. Forget-Nothing uses memory and tools.
relationships.knows_too_much: Both know too much. Different knowledge. Mutual burden.
relationships.bird_gatherer: Works alongside. Both do multiple jobs. Forget-Nothing teaches, Gatherer learns.

animal_companion.name: Single white pig, no name
animal_companion.description: One white pig. Large. Follows everywhere. Seems to forget Forget-Nothing constantly—wanders off, returns surprised. The irony is noted by everyone, explained by no one.
animal_companion.externalized_impulse: The desire to forget. To not carry everything. The pig embodies the release of memory that Forget-Nothing can't access.
